CICERO To BRUTUS

Rome, middle of June, 43 B.c.

I have so far received no letter from you, no, nor 1 even a rumour to notify me that you were acquainted with the Senate's resolution and were bringing an army to Italy. The free state is most anxious that you should do so, and that quickly‚ for our home troubles are growing more serious every day, and our difficulties with our enemies in the field are no greater than with those inside the gate. These enemies were present since the very beginning of the war, but it used to be easier to suppress them. The Senate had been encouraged‚ not only by our formal statements of opinion, but also by our calls fo action, to take up a stiffer attitude.
